 BOLIVIA NATIONAL LAND ADMINISTRATION PROJECT INTRODUCTION 1. The weak legal, institutional, and technical framework of Bolivia's land administration system was identified in the late 1980s and reported in various sector studies and Staff Appraisal Reports. Land Administration has also been a regular theme in the policy dialogue between the Bolivian Government and IDA. In July 1992, IDA sent a mission to analyze the land tenure issues in particular the granting of public land in parcels far exceeding the grantee's exploitation capacities. The mission reported on the increasing land insecurity in the Eastern Lowlands because of overlapping titles and poor performance of the land institutions. An agreement was reached on the need to design a comprehensive solution for Bolivia's land administration system. 2. In November 1992, Government decided to start clarifying the land tenure situation by suspending the operations of the National Commission of Agrarian Reform (CNRA) and the National Colonization Institute (INC) which were in charge of land reform, titling and land settlements. It introduced a moratorium on the distribution of public land and created the Comisi6n de Intervenci6n CNRA-INC (CI), inspecting the operations of CNRA and INC and carrying out some of their mandate. CI has started to overhaul the entire land legislation, draft legal reforms, work on the backlog of the past land titling programs, and design a land settlement policy. A specific request for IDA support followed in February 1993. CI's establishment has been largely financed through reallocation of proceeds of the Development Credit 21 19-BO. In mid-1993, additional funding from the Japanese Trust Fund was approved to finance preparation of the proposed project, including implementation of a pilot cadastral project. 3. An IDA pre-appraisal mission visited Bolivia in April 1994. It was followed by an appraisal mission in July 1994 and a follow-up mission in November 1994. Negotiations took place in March 1995.

 1. BACKGROUND A. The Macro-Economic Situation 1.1 Faced with a severe economic crisis in de mid-1980s, Bolivia was one of the first countries in Latin America to adopt a far reaching economic program aimed at restoring price stability and restructuring the economy. The economic reform program combined comprehensive structural reforms with tight monetary policy and a program to reduce debt and debt service payments. This has resulted in restoring price stability and economic growth-real GDP growth has been an annual four percent in recent years. 1.2 Bolivia's economy remains fragile. The 1994 fiscal deficit-3.2 percent of GDP-was, however, significantly lower than the 1993 deficit. The external position remains weak--although the 12-month current account deficit (after official transfers) decreased to 5 percent of GDP in 1994. Moreover, Bolivia remains vulnerable to exogenous shocks-most importantly changes in external aid and in international commodity prices. 1.3 The modest economic growth achieved in the past five years has not significantly reduced poverty levels. Over half of the population remains poor and the poverty gap has widened. The modest growth level can in part be explained by a decade- long decline in the net accumulation of capital stock. While private investment has recovered it remains at a modest level of seven percent of GDP. Public investment has been relatively high--about ten percent of GDP--yet to a large extend, resources have been poorly allocated and invested inefficiently. 1.4 The new Government came into power in August 1993 and is committed to macroeconomic stability and a set of reforms intended to accelerate growth and reduce poverty. The Government has acted aggressively--and so far successfully- to correct the fiscal equilibrium which emerged in 1993. The inflation rate has declined from 10 percent in 1993 to 8.5 percent at the end of 1994. B. The Natural Resources Base 1.5 Land Area. Bolivia's territory covers 1.1 million km2. It is divided into three distinct agro-climatic regions: the highland plateau (Altiplano) in the west, the inter- Andean Valleys (some semi-arid, some humnid) in the center, and the flat tropical Lowlands in the East. During a census in 1984, 20 percent of the land (22 million ha) were identified having an owner. Of those lands, more than nine million ha are forest, about 11 million ha are natural grasslands, and two million are cultivated or fallow. Good agricultural land is relatively scarce and is found mainly in valley bottoms, lakeshores and alluvial plains. Various sources indicate that forests and woodlands comprise roughly 50

Bolivia is a sparsely populated country (6.4 million people or 6.4 inhabitants per km2). The population has a great cultural diversity that encompasses several ethnic groups and languages shaping a society marked by sharp contrasts. The country's rural population is concentrated in the Andean regions. With 38 percent of the land area, the Highland Plateau and Valleys account for 71 percent of the people (Highland Plateau 45 percent, Valleys 26 percent). The Lowlands have extremely low population densities. The uneven distribution of the population brings the country's natural resources under pressure. Concentration of rural families in the more favorable areas of the Highland Plateau and the Valleys has led to overexploitation. As a result, vegetative cover has been lost, wind and water erosion has accelerated and soil fertility has declined. There are very few remaining forests in those areas, with the exception of the humid tropical valleys. By contrast, with a rural population of only half a million people and an area of 60 million ha, the Lowlands have considerable agricultural, livestock and forestry potential. According to a recently completed land use plan, the Department of Santa Cruz alone has some four million ha of good agricultural land, out of which only 0.6 million ha are cultivated. Several million hectares are available for extensive livestock raising. 1.7 Agriculture. Agriculture comprises a very poor traditional subsector located mainly in the Highland Plateau and Valleys and a modem subsector coexisting with small-scale traditional farmers located in the tropical Lowlands. 1.8 Contribution to GDP. In terms of contribution to GDP and employment, agriculture is an important sector of the Bolivian economy. In 1992, it accounted for 20.4 percent of GDP and employed 45 percent of the labor force. Legal agricultural exports have fluctuated between US$160 million and US$230 million over the last few years, representing between 20 percent and 25 percent of the country's total export earnings. The sector has been growing at a modest 1.5 percent in real terms since 1987, following the liberalization of the economy in the mid-80s. This modest growth was mainly generated by the modem subsector which seized the opportunity presented by the stable economy and oriented most of its new investment towards exports. Area expansion through land clearing, especially for soybean production in the Lowlands, has been
 - 3 - especially important during that period. By contrast, the traditional sector did not respond as anticipated to favorable price adjustments, because of the lack of growth potential and markets, lack of technologies adapted to the extreme climatic conditions and the absence of support services, including rural infrastructure and agricultural extension. 1.9 Traditional agriculture accounts for 65 percent of agriculture's gross value of legal production and is concentrated on small farms (usually less than five ha, called minifundios). It is practiced under harsh climatic and environmental conditions with rudimentary technology and minimal Government support. On the Highland Plateau, conditions are especially severe with high risk of crop failures due to drought, hail and frost. Maize, potatoes, barley, and quinoa cereals are the most important crops. In the Valleys, conditions are more favorable, and intensification is possible with irrigation. Overall yields have remained unchanged in the past twenty years and income from crops is insufficient to cover basic necessities. Consequently, most rural families have diversified into cottage industries, seasonal migration and petty commerce, and have tried to develop links to the urban economy. Despite these additional sources of income, traditional farmers are amongst the poorest, and have been largely bypassed by the country's development and modernization. 1.10 Modern agriculture comprises medium and large holdings, ranging from 50 to tens of thousands of ha, geared to the production of export and some import substitution crops, cattle and timber. These holdings practice mechanized agriculture, extensive livestock raising and/or hold vast extensions of land for future development. The main exported commodities are soybeans and timber. In recent years this sector has shown considerable dynarism and growth potential. 1.11 Farm Structure. According to in the 1984 agricultural census, there are 314,600 farms covering almost 23 million hectares (including livestock pastures). The size of about 70 percent of the farms does not exceed five ha. These small farms cover only 1.5 percent of the total farm area. At the other end of the spectrum, 1.5 percent of the holdings occupy about 70 percent ofthe farm area.' 1.12 Forest Potential. The Lowlands also boast one of the world's largest tropical forest areas (45 million ha). These areas are very rich in biodiversity. For most of Bolivia's history, these forests were a distant, inaccessible, and extremely unpopulated place. This started changing in the 1950's when improved road links and the development of the oil industry in Santa Cruz triggered a process of dramatic changes. The influx of physical and human capital that followed led initially to the development of livestock and agriculture, and later to the development of an export-led forest industry. 1.13 Land Tenure. The rapid growth of agricultural, livestock, and forestry activities has raised increasing concerns about natural resources degradation, primarily deforestation, extinction of timber species (e.g., mahogany), soil erosion, fertility decline, and loss of biodiversity. The impact of agricultural and logging activities on the welfare of the indigenous peoples in the Lowlands has also become a source of major concern. Effective demarcation of protected areas and indigenous territories, development of land use plans to classify different areas, and introduction of environmentally sustainable agricultural practices are today priorities to improve overall natural resources management in the region. C. Present Land Administration 1.16 The present Land Administration includes the following functions: (i) titling; (ii) maintenance of a cadastre; (iii) land registration and land information management; and (iv) acquisition of land for new settlements. Land Titling 1.17 Titling is the initial granting of land to private owners. In the past, CNRA and INC were responsible for land titling. CNRA had jurisdiction over the entire country, while INC had jurisdiction over legally defined settlement areas, thereby overlapping with CNRA. Lack of coordination between these two agencies and absence of a geographical backup of the titling process often gave rise to overlapping titles or proliferation of multiple titles to the same parcels. The cadastral agency in Santa Cruz has attempted to produce a consolidated map of land ownership based on property descriptions registered in the cadastre. The map reveals overlapping claims on some 40 percent of the land. The situation on the ground is yet another reality, which has only remote resemblance with the legal records. 1.18 The titling process in Bolivia has been notoriously slow and cumbersome, except for people able to find their way through the administrative maze. Titling procedures have been highly centralized and conducive to administrative irregularities, contained an excessive number of steps, and involved high cost and completion times. On average it took CNRA and INC respectively 12 and 7 years to process a land title. This
 -6 - state of affairs has been most detrimental to the small beneficiaries of the land reform, while very large lots were sometimes titled very quickly. The backlog of the 40-year old land reform titling program is only now being cleared. 1.19 The proliferation and inconsistency in the land titles, and lack of recording and updating in the Property Registry are main problems. The consequences are most severe in the area of expansion of the Eastern Lowlands, where they are a source of tenure insecurity depressing land values, causing a reluctance to invest, encouraging extensive land use, and accelerating expansion of the agricultural frontier. In the traditional areas of the country, where community organizations are strong, tenure insecurity is less prevalent. The cohesiveness and internal organization of these communities means that land holding within the community is tightly controlled and limited to recognized members of the community. Land disputes are therefore much less frequent than in the Lowlands and are resolved through community mechanisms. Hence, local disputes are not the main source of insecurity among traditional farmers and their interest in holding reliable titles. Traditional farmers perceive the need to set the official records straight. Cadastre 1.20 A cadastre is a complete graphic record (cadastral mosaic) of all parcels in a jurisdiction. A distinction has to be made between a fiscal and a legal cadastre. A fiscal cadastre surveys and records information describing the geographic dimensions of property parcels. The fiscal cadastre is not necessarily very accurate as it records only information useful for property assessment. The legal cadastre surveys and records information describing the geographic dimensions of property parcels very accurately, as well as the nature of the land rights and the holders of those rights. 1.21 There exists no legal cadastre in Bolivia, but there are fiscal and rural cadastres. The urban areas have a fiscal cadastre, administered by the Municipalities under the guidance of the National Direction of Urban Cadastre (Direcci6n Nacional de Catastro Urbano, DNCU). The Military Geographic Institute (Instituto Geogr4fico Militar, IGM), which is in charge of the country's geodetic control network and the production of maps. IGM merely registers rural properties and sometimes collects certain taxes. In practice however, 16 IGM regional offices have had very few resources to carry out this work. Although they have done some mapping of individual parcels, they have not created comprehensive, up-to-date records of land parcels in any jurisdiction. As a result, no information on the topographic position of the parcels is acquired and they cannot be placed accurately on a map. Records of the boundaries of protected areas are also inaccurate. Attempts to put all those maps together show overlap and gaps. Registry 1.22 Registration is the process of entering in official records a set of legal information which describes the holders of the land rights, the nature and basis of these rights, as well as spatial information regarding the area, geographic location, and parcel dimensions. The process of registration includes new title registration, but more
 - 7 - importantly it also involves the recording of any transaction that modifies, extinguishes or creates tenure rights. Hence, once land records (the legal cadastre) have been created, registration is essential for their long term maintenance. 1.23 The Property Registry (Derechos Reales, DDRR), a dependency of the Supreme Court, is responsible for registering urban and rural property. The present registry has a rudimentary registration of deeds system in which contracts and documents of conveyance are recorded. This inscription in a public office is designed to provide security to landholders against third parties by publicizing land transactions. DDRR's operation and management, however, has not evolved since its establishment in the beginning of the century. Registration is slow and inefficient. Departmental Registry offices are independent from each other and report directly to the Supreme Court. The Court takes decisions on registry matters in full session. 1.24 Only a small portion of rural titles issued over the last 40 years have been registered. Similarly, land transactions are not systematically registered. Hence, the Registry is far from complete. Moreover, registered titles may not correspond to the actual delimitation of the property as the linkage with the rural cadastre is very weak, and the cadastre itself is unreliable. Reasons for the low percentage of registered titles can be attributed to the following: (i) over-centralization of DDRR offices creating accessibility problems for small farmers; (ii) lack of appreciation for the security that registration provides against third parties; (iii) high costs associated with time spent and fees/taxes that have to be paid as part of the registration process; and (iv) absence of a legal cadastre. Settlement Programs 1.25 Settlement efforts go back as far as the early 1950s and were thought to serve three purposes: (i) expand agricultural production; (ii) alleviate population pressures in the Highland Plateau; and (iii) dilute isolationist tendencies within the Santa Cruz region. These objectives have somehow been met, although sometimes at high financial costs. After the Government-directed settlement approach failed, INC lost support from external funding agencies and was unable to get domestic budget support. Consequently, INC adopted a more modest approach towards settlement programs. Financially ambitious projects, which characterized the 1970s, were abandoned and paternalism was replaced by individual initiative. Later interventions have been in support of semi-directed land settlements, with INC responsible for the titling of land, and, funds permitting, providing some basic infrastructure. These schemes have had better results. Today, however, as the majority of settlement takes place spontaneously, there is little control that this process is in accordance with land capabilities and environmental concerns.
 -8 - 2. THE PROPOSED LAND REFORM PROCESS A. Legal Framework 2.1 Bolivia's current land legal framework is based on the Agrarian Reform Law of 1953, which was formulated to support the transfer of large private domains to peasants in the traditional agricultural areas of the Highland Plateau and the Valleys. At that time, Bolivia had a very skewed land distribution pattern, with four percent of the landowners controlling more than 82 percent of the land. CNRA redistributed large private properties (latifiadios) in small lots to peasants, and distributed most public land (tierrasfiscales) to much larger and fewer beneficiaries. Overall, CNRA's records show that it re-allocated some 45 million ha or 40 percent of the country's territory over a forty year period. 2.2 Inadequacy of the Legal Framework The present legal framework is inadequate to deal with Bolivia's present agrarian problems and has led to many constraints to agricultural growth and natural resources management. The current legislation fails to acknowledge the current heterogeneous nature of the land tenure structure. Excessive restrictions on land transactions (i.e., sales, tenancy, inheritances, subdivisions)--although quite frequently ignored--have led to rigidities in the land market and consequent inefficiencies in resources allocation. Free allocation of public lands has led to a very uneven land distribution pattem. As a consequence of an arbitrary land allocation policy, and in conjunction with grossly inaccurate mapping of the titles issued, double titling, superposition of conflicting rights (between farmers, ranchers, indigenous peoples, forest reserves, national parks, etc.) has created widespread tenure insecurity in the Lowlands. Superposition of conflicting rights has made it increasingly difficult to design and implement a sound natural resources management strategy. The reversion4 provision introduced as a means to enforce the fundamental concept of "working the land" as the criteria for establishing property rights, has had the unintended consequence of aggravating tenure insecurity in conflict areas. The legislation also fails to recognize the role of communal organizations in defining property rights, preserving tenure security, and resolving conflicts. The historical rights of indigenous peoples in the Amazonian Basin and the Chaco region have not been effectively preserved. 2.3 Need for Reform of the Land Legislation. There is a consensus in Bolivia that the Agrarian Reform Law has outlived its primary purpose of eliminating latifundio. Instead, the inadequate institutional set up to carry out the Agrarian Reform was ill-used to give away enormous amounts of public lands to individuals. This process created incentives for significant land speculation and other distortions in the rural land markets. Findings from literature suggest that the productivity differential favoring small and medium-sized family farms over large ones tend to increase with differences in size. 4 Reversion had perverse effects because whoever initiated the process could apply for ownership of the same land. Renting out one's plot could be used as reason for claiming abandonment by the legitimate owner and for initiating the reversion process.
 Hence, a negative relation between farm size and productivity is likely to exist in Bolivia. A more equitable land distribution would not only be desirable from a social point of view, but that also efficiency gains can be realized by pursuing this goal. Removing distortions in rural land markets and creating effective mechanisms (including Government support) to facilitate access of small farmers to land are the major challenges for the formulation of a new land policy framework underlying the establishment of an improved land administration system. In addition, the removal of land insecurity is likely to encourage longer- term investment in land and the introduction of more sustainable farming systems. B. Government Land Policy Political and Institutional Context 2.4 In view of the problems with CNRA and INC--especially the discretionary allocations of very large land areas and administrative irregularities--Government suspended their activities in late 1992. The Comisi6n de Intervenci6n (CI), was set up to investigate their past practices. At the same time, Government introduced a moratorium on the allocation of public land for extensions in excess of 50 ha per beneficiary. In March 1993, CI effectively took over some duties and prerogatives of INC and CNRA, as a transitional arrangement pending the creation of a new land titling agency. 2.5 CI's present mandate covers the following: (i) to study the territorial planning with respect to land use, the location, size and demarcation of the land areas granted, consolidated and adjudicated by the State, the vacant land areas and areas reverted to the State; (ii) to identify overlaps in agricultural, settlement and forest zones, border conflicts, double titling and de-facto land possession; (iii) to establish irregularities and illegalities in land acquisition in general; (iv) to propose laws and regulations to rectify inaccurate situations; (v) to reorganize the offices of CNRA and INC; (vi) to provide statistics on land allocation and titling since the initiation of the agrarian reform program and the creation of INC, specifying its shortcomings; (vii) to continue with the titling of ongoing land title requests; and (viii) identify, assess and reserve public lands for distribution to small farners. CI has started examining previous grants, and, where necessary, has recommended the annulment of titles. It is also reformulating Government policy and institutional reforn for the land sector. 2.6 Bolivia's new Government took office in August 1993 and enacted two major laws setting the framework for the reformn of land administration institutions and processes. It created a Ministry of Sustainable Development and Environment (Ministerio de Desarrollo Sostenible y del Medio Ambiente, MDSMA), responsible for managing the reform of land policies and institutions. CI reports to MDSMA. It also introduced the Popular Participation Law, which creates 301 Municipalities and expands their jurisdiction to include the rural areas. The law specifies that the Municipalities are responsible for the administration of the fiscal cadastre.
 - 10- Land Policy 2.7 To redress the deficiencies of the current legislation and consistent with the priorities of the Government, five key principles are likely to guide the creation and management of the land institutions and the drafting of new land legislation: (i) tenure security for all types of owners; (ii) equity in the access to fiscal lands; (iii) efficiency in resources allocation; (iv) sustainability in natural resources management; and (v) transparency in land administration. Land distribution policy will be part of a comprehensive land use plan integrating various alternative resource uses such as protected areas, indigenous territories and forestry concessions. Strategy 2.8 The Government is committed to address the major shortcomings of the current legislation by enhancing the present land administration system in anticipation of the presentation to Congress of laws which would create a National Land Institute and a Legal Cadastral Registry. It would also present to Congress a framework land law, that will legislate the new Government policy with regard to property rights and the distribution of public land. To this end, it has established a technical working group led by CI to discuss key changes, consult with all interested sectors, and present a Government proposal to Congress not later than December 1997. The Government has specified publicly that the new land legislation will be based on broad popular consultations. Proposed Reform of the Land Tenure Legislation 2.9 Government intends to pass a Land Law which will set the broad principles of the new land tenure legislation, to be followed by detailed regulations, and several other laws as required. Lessons from Experience 3.6 A recent review of Bank experience with land administration projects indicates that in largely agrarian economies, such as Bolivia, land rights are an immensely political matter. When a program involves some redistribution rights over land, political opposition is likely to be intense unless compensation to those relinquishing those rights is considerable. Second, the complexity of the land titling process has often been underestimated. Land titling efforts have to commit considerable resources to institutional development so there are sufficient technical and human capacities available for efficient project implementation. Third, even with adequate capacity, there is no quick-fix to land tenure problems. Improvements in this field can only be achieved on a long-term basis. These lessons are being incorporated in the design of the project through initial support to a first phase project, designed to obtain broad political approval for the reforms, strengthen institutional capabilities, and address the pressing needs of conflict areas. 3.7 A review of experiences with land settlement schemes identified a number of important lessons, which have been incorporated in the design of the Project. First, no settlement programn can succeed without a clear tenure policy. Technical efficiency and economic viability are best served by a program design that promotes individual land holding through the issue of freehold titles or other long-term usufruct agreements. Second, the size of the holding allocated to settlers is an important factor in attracting them and determining agricultural incomes. Outcomes will be more successful if land area allocations are in line with educational levels, agricultural skills and experience, the available family labor force and those capital assets that allow land to be managed. Third, there is massive evidence of success in association with settlement on good soils and in a favorable climate. This points out the importance of proper site selection based on land use plans. Fourth, excessive paternalism in scheme organization and administration on the part of the administering agency and associated personnel should be avoided at all cost. A great deal of evidence points to the conclusion that the emergence of strong, self-reliant groups among settler communities is a vital ingredient in ensuring the sustainability of settlement programs. Fifth, the emphasis that all infrastructure and social services should be provided before settlers arrive and must be provided by the state is wrong. Safe water supplies should be present when settlers move in, and roads should follow without much delay. There appears to be a positive association between extension and agricultural success. The provision of credit in general has a poor recovery record, except if strongly linked to output marketing. E. First, public land allocations through land grants (or sales) would follow existing land use plans and, if necessary, supplemental soil suitability studies would be carried out. The Land Settlement Manual would specify how soil classification of land use plans would relate to the intended use (agriculture, livestock) of land allocations. New limits, based on soil studies and land use plans would be incorporated into the new Land Law.

The 1953 Agrarian Reform the legal and institutional system has played a key role in land redistribution and elimination of latifundio. In case an officially designated buffer zone does not exist, no public land parcel would be granted or sold by the Government within five km of any official protected area. (v) In the case of Santa Cruz Department, lands would not be available for small farmer grants or sales if they lie within the zones designated as "Forest", "Existing Protection", or "Proposed Protection" under the official land use plan (PLUT). The Santa Cruz PLUT was developed under the Eastern Lowlands Natural Resources Management and Agricultural Production Project (Credit No. 21 19-BO). In the future, if other land use plans are approved by other departments and/or at the national level, land settlements and sales would be made fully consistent with those plans. 9. Selection of Settlers. In the selection of potential settlers for the land settlement program (in cases where excess demand for the lands exists), special consideration would be given to persons who currently live within "zones of environmental conflict" (including long-established squatters within protected areas). This approach is expected to enhance further the environmental benefits of this project, by reducing existing land pressures within environmentally sensitive areas.
 - 83 - 10. Land Parcel Size. Settlers in the Latin American tropics have historically been allocated relatively large land parcels, which has reinforced their tendency to select extensive land uses (such as cattle pastures rather than more labor-intensive perennial crops). To promote more efficient land use, the basic unit of land allocation in the land settlement program would be determined through technical criteria based on the following objectives: (i) to ensure that every participating family has enough land to build a future for one generation; (ii) to maximize the number of beneficiary families on the lands available for distribution; and (iii) to minimize the land area deforested per fhmily. 11. Titling of Indigenous Lands. The project would substantially benefit indigenous people by providing valid, well-defined land titles to many indigenous communities. In the process, the need for a sufficient land base to enable the continuation of traditional production systems (including hunting, fishing, gathering, and shifting cultivation) would be carefully considered. In the case of indigenous communities which receive communal land titles (in accordance with Convention 169 of the International Labor Organization), INTI would develop regulations and procedures to help prevent fraud or other abuses if the indigenous communities elect to rent out their lands to outsiders (e.g., for lumbering or ranching). 12. Avoiding Perverse Incentives For Deforestation. Land titling procedures in Latin American countries are often blamed for creating "perverse incentives" which encourage (or even require) deforestation to consolidate private land claims. To avoid this problem, the new Land Law and Forestry Law are expected to state clearly that deforestation is neither necessary nor sufficient for obtaining new land titles, nor for protecting existing, legally valid titles. Even if these new laws do not deal with this issue adequately, the Government has specified its commitment to avoid rewarding new or recent deforestation in its land titling policies and procedures. Aerial photography would be used to establish a benchmark for the determination of actual land use. 13. Land Policy Analysis Unit. The new Land Policy Analysis Unit (Unidad de Analisis de Politica de Tierras, UDAPTI) in the Ministry of Environmentally Sustainable Development would be a high-level advisory body on national land policy issues. To help ensure adequate consideration of environmental issues in its work, UDAPTI would have at least one natural resources management specialist (such as a biologist, ecologist, or forester). This requirement is specified in the terms of reference for establishing the UDAPTI.

doc.abstracts: The objectives of the National Land Administration Project will be to achieve a more efficient and transparent land administration system, clarify the land tenure situation, identify public land suitable for small farmer settlements and promote a more sustainable use of the country's land resources. The project will have a major component improving the land administration system within the current framework and a minor component implementing the legal and institutional land administration reforms, if and when they are introduced. The major component will support the formulation of a sound and coherent land policy and legislation, carry out land mapping on three million ha to obtain cadastre information and to regularize the land tenure situation wherever possible, indentify 500,000 ha suitable for small farmer settlement and increase the efficiency and transparency of the land administration system. In addition, the project will also finance: 1) title regularization and land settlement programs by the National Land Institute, when established; and 2) the introduction of an integrated legal cadastral registry system when the Legal Cadastral Registry is established.
